## Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's Wartime Exile and Writing of *The Little Prince*

After the collapse of France, he fled to the United States, spending the next couple of years there and in Canada advocating for the liberation of his country from German occupation and also denouncing the Vichy French rump state that collaborated with the Nazis.(no content)It was during his time in the United States that Saint-Exupéry wrote The Little Prince, which was published there in 1943.

### The 1942 New York Period

Saint-Exupéry wrote and illustrated The Little Prince in New York City and the village of Asharoken in mid-to-late 1942, with the manuscript being completed in October.(no content)Although greeted warmly by French-speaking Americans and by fellow expatriates who had preceded him in New York, his 27-month stay would be marred by health problems and racked with periods of severe stress and marital strife.(no content)Between January 1941 and April 1943, the Saint-Exupérys lived in two penthouse apartments on Central Park South, then, at the Delamater-Bevin Mansion in Asharoken, Long Island, where The book was written during the fall and winter of 1942 in the twenty-two-room Bevin House built by industrialist Cornelius DeLamater.

### Inspiration for *The Little Prince*

After he returned from his stay in Québec, which had been fraught with illness and stress, the wife of one of his publishers helped persuade Saint-Exupéry to produce a children's book, hoping to calm his nerves and In the spring of 1942, his French publisher encouraged him to think about writing a children's book, something that could compete with P. L. Travers's Mary Poppins series.

The character of the little prince was inspired by a precocious eight-year-old with curly blond hair while he was residing with a family in Quebec City in 1942, Thomas De Koninck, the son of philosopher Charles De Koninck.(no content)The Saint-Exupérys also resided in Quebec City, Canada for several weeks during the late spring of 1942. During their time in Quebec City, the family lived with the philosopher Charles De Koninck and his family, including his "precocious" 8-year-old son, Thomas.

### Writing Process and Publication

He wrote and illustrated the manuscript during the summer and fall of 1942.(no content)The Little Prince was published in the United States in English and French in early 1943.(no content)However, the period was to be both a "dark but productive time" during which he created three important works.

### Contemporary Accounts
- After his disappearance, Consuelo de Saint-Exupéry wrote The Tale of the Rose, which was published in 2000 and subsequently translated into 16 languages.

### Academic Recognition
Stacy Schiff, one of Saint-Exupéry's principal biographers, wrote of him and his most famous work, "rarely have an author and a character been so intimately bound together as Antoine de Saint-Exupéry and his Little Prince", demonstrating the close connection between the author's life experiences and his literary work during this crucial period of wartime exile.
